1.title: Jiao Yunlong Family: Intro
1.plot: Hailing from Yunnan province in China, Jiao Yunlong and Zhang Hui's older son Jiao Tong has Niemann-Pick Type C. Learn more about the Jiao Yunlong family's fight against NPC.

2.title: Jiao Yunlong Family: Family Life
2.plot: "We want him to feel that the love from his father stands as a mountain, and the love from his mother flows as a stream."

3.title: Jiao Yunlong Family: Symptoms
3.plot: Jiao Tong was once physically active, bringing a basketball to school daily. However, he began to lose his interest in sports and to have difficulty balancing, walking and swallowing.

4.title: Jiao Yunlong Family: NPC Diagnosis
4.plot: When Jiao Tong was 12 years old he was hospitalized for a fever, but the doctors couldn't find what was wrong. After many tests, including genetic testing, he was diagnosed with Niemann Pick type C.

5.title: Jiao Yunlong Family: Previous Treatment
5.plot: In September 2014, Jiao Tong's parents brought him to Taiwan to buy miglustat. However, they could only get a small supply of the drug and they saw no benefit from it.

6.title: Jiao Yunlong Family: Learning About Cyclodextrin
6.plot: After much searching for a treatment for Jiao Tong's NPC disease, his parents learned of VTS-270 (cyclodextrin) and the Vtesse trial in the US.

7.title: Jiao Yunlong Family: Vtesse Phase II/III Trial
7.plot: Jiao Yunlong and Zhang Hui are optimistic that VTS-270 (cyclodextrin) will improve their son's quality of life.

8.title: Jiao Yunlong Family: Coming to the US
8.plot: "[Our friend] helped us find a place to live where there are many Chinese people; this will help with the language trouble, food and other struggles."

9.title: Tong Wei Family: Family Life
9.plot: "[When my son was eight years old,] we received an invitation and brought him to the US to participate in a clinical trial."

10.title: Tong Wei Family: Early Symptoms
10.plot: Tong Weibing lacked motor coordination and had difficulty walking, paying attention, and moving his eyes.

11.title: Tong Wei Family: Previous Treatment
11.plot: Tong Weibing's family traveled to Europe to buy medication for him, but were unable to get it. He remained, for the most part, untreated.

12.title: Tong Wei Family: Symptom Progression
12.plot: Tong Weibing started to have seizures and to fall down when walking; he also began to choke and to get tired easily.

13.title: Tong Wei Family: Vtesse Phase II/III Trial
13.plot: Tong Wei and Zhang Ye heard about the Vtesse cyclodextrin trial from fellow China NPC community member, Jiao Yunlong.

14.title: Tong Wei Family: Coming to the US
14.plot: Tong Wei and his family found the different language and culture in the US - as well as the higher cost of living - challenging.

15.title: Tong Wei Family: Hope for VTS-270
15.plot: Tong Weibing's parents are hopeful that cyclodextrin treatment will improve his NPC symptoms.

16.title: Tong Wei Family: Hope for the Future
16.plot: Tong Wei and Zhang Ye hope their family's action will contribute to a better future for other NPC patients and, one day, to a cure.

1.title: Hempel Family: Symptoms of NPC
1.plot: "The obvious things were they had an enlarged spleen and a mildly enlarged liver...verbal things and some of the other more dramatic stuff came along quite a bit later."

2.title: Hempel Family: Using Cyclodextrin
2.plot: "Right now Cassi gets the injection in her back and Addi gets her injection right into a little port that's just right below her scalp. We do that because the outcome of the Niemann-Pick disease is well understood..."

3.title: Hempel Family: Early Intervention Cyclodextrin
3.plot: "It might be really hard as a parent to take that step if your child is fully functional...if you know the child has NPC, the earlier the intervention you can do, the better."

4.title: Hempel Family: Results of Cyclodextrin
4.plot: Since starting cyclodextrin, the Hempels have seen not only seen a halt to the progression of symptoms, but have even seen improvements.

5.title: Hempel Family: Cannabis Oil
5.plot: "We started implementing cannabis oil into their program and we've seen a pretty big reduction in their seizures..."

6.title: Hadley Family: Family Life
6.plot: "It's extremely difficult to keep life 'normal' for the family. Any family with a rare disease knows this."

7.title: Hadley Family: Symptoms of NPC
7.plot: For many years, Bryan and Laura didn't know their kids had NPC, and doctors didn't test for it. One telltale symptom - an enlarged spleen - could have told them otherwise.

8.title: Hadley Family: Juvenile Onset of NPC
8.plot: A lot changed for Peyton when his symptoms manifested at eight years old. In many ways, however, he's the same kid.

9.title: Hadley Family: Using Cyclodextrin
9.plot: "We had to drive six hours south to Oakland every two weeks...but we felt so strongly that the cyclodextrin was working and helping that this is something we really needed to do for our kids."

10.title: Hadley Family: Early Intervention Cyclodextrin
10.plot: Since the damage NPC does to neural pathways is irreversible, the Hadleys pursued early intervention with their children.

11.title: Hadley Family: Results of Cyclodextrin
11.plot: After Peyton began cyclodextrin treatment, both his speech and gait improved noticeably.

12.title: Hadley Family: Intravenous  Cyclodextrin at Home
12.plot: "We spent about a thousand hours in the hospital until we finally said, 'Why can't we do this at home?'"

13.title: Hadley Family: Pursuing Cyclodextrin
13.plot: "Ultimately, the decision to start cyclodextrin started because we just couldn't wait any longer."

14.title: Hadley Family: Cannabis Oil
14.plot: "Peyton is prone to seizures...[cannabis oil] controls the intensity of the seizures and the regularity of them."

15.title: Dr. Caroline Hastings: Intro
15.plot: Dr. Hastings has over 15 years' experience treating cancer in children, and works in the Neuro-Oncology Program at Children's Hospital & Research Center Oakland.

16.title: Dr. Caroline Hastings: Results of Cyclodextrin Hadley Family
16.plot: After treatment, Peyton told his family and doctor that he could think more clearly and focus better.

17.title: Dr. Caroline Hastings: Results of Cyclodextrin Hempel Family
17.plot: With cyclodextrin, the girls have a higher quality of life, and are alive.

18.title: Dr. Caroline Hastings: Intravenous  Cyclodextrin
18.plot: This was the first treatment method for Addi and Cassi - a continuous infusion of cyclodextrin over 4 days.

19.title: Dr. Caroline Hastings: Intrathecal (IT) Cyclodextrin
19.plot: In October 2012, Addi and Cassi began to receive cyclodextrin directly into the spinal fluid.

20.title: Dr. Caroline Hastings: Intracerebral  Cyclodextrin
20.plot: Addi gets cyclodextrin by a third method: intracerebral (ICV) treatment via a port in her scalp.

21.title: Dr. Caroline Hastings: Pursuing Cyclodextrin
21.plot: Knowing that early-onset NPC meant that Addi and Cassi were only expected to live to the age of 10, Hugh and Chris made it their mission to find a way to help their daughters.

22.title: Dr. Caroline Hastings: Recommending Cyclodextrin
22.plot: For families battling NPC, choosing cyclodextrin comes with risks. The benefits, however, are potentially huge.

23.title: Dr. Diane Williams: Early Intervention Cyclodextrin
23.plot: Giving Kayla cyclodextrin early stabilized her NPC and kept her asymptomatic years after her diagnosis.

24.title: Dr. Diane Williams: Results of Cyclodextrin
24.plot: In both Peyton and Kayla, cyclodextrin treatment brought the disease's progress to a standstill.

25.title: Honsinger Family: Family Life
25.plot: "Now we have a new normal...We have to be caregivers, we have to be strong, and it's not easy."

26.title: Honsinger Family: Symptoms of NPC
26.plot: "Mollie mentioned how, when her brother Jay would laugh, he would sometimes, like, collapse a little bit. It turns out it was cataplexy."

27.title: Honsinger Family: Using Cyclodextrin
27.plot: "The only bad thing we heard was loss of hearing. And we decided we would rather have a deaf child than no child at all."

28.title: Honsinger Family: Early Intervention Cyclodextrin
28.plot: Time is crucial when it comes to treating NPC - even the three to four months it took for JP to get cyclodextrin could have prevented irreversible damage.

29.title: Honsinger Family: Results of Cyclodextrin
29.plot: "A year ago, he wasn't talking, it was like one-word answers. He talks now, again."

30.title: Honsinger Family: Recommending Cyclodextrin
30.plot: "I would absolutely 100 percent recommend it, and it's the reason I'm driving to Washington to talk to them."

31.title: Dr. Anne Nepo: Intro
31.plot: Dr. Nepo is associate professor of clinical pediatrics at Albany Medical College, and works at the Melodies Center for treatment of children's cancer and blood diseases at Albany Medical Center.

32.title: Dr. Anne Nepo: Symptoms of NPC
32.plot: JP had abnormal eye movement and trouble with cataplexy - a condition that causes the patient to suddenly lose muscle tone.

33.title: Dr. Anne Nepo: Results of Cyclodextrin
33.plot: JP's cataplexy has improved, and his symptoms show no signs of progression.

34.title: Dr. Anne Nepo: Intrathecal (IT) Cyclodextrin
34.plot: Receiving intrathecal cyclodextrin can be anxiety-inducing for your child. Calm, supportive parents and nurses are the most important factor in easing the process.

35.title: Dr. Anne Nepo: Pursuing Cyclodextrin
35.plot: Dr. Nepo's background in oncology and hematology made her an ideal candidate for performing JP's intrathecal injections.

36.title: Dr. Anne Nepo: Recommending Cyclodextrin
36.plot: Cyclodextrin should be administered under the careful eye of a neurologist, and you should be certain your child has Niemann-Pick Type C and not a disorder with similar symptoms.

37.title: Dr. Anne Nepo: The Unknow of Cyclodextrin
37.plot: Many drugs Dr. Nepo uses in her job as a pediatric oncologist are not formally approved for children, so the use of a promising drug like cyclodextrin is not unusual.

38.title: Dr. John Pugh: Intro
38.plot: Dr. Pugh is an assistant professor of pediatrics and neurology at Albany Medical College.

39.title: Dr. John Pugh: Symptoms of NPC
39.plot: NPC hampered JP's ability to walk, speak and swallow.

40.title: Dr. John Pugh: Early Intervention Cyclodextrin
40.plot: Treating Niemann-Pick Type C early is especially important due to its chronic, degenerative nature.

41.title: Dr. John Pugh: Results of Cyclodextrin
41.plot: JP takes monthly fine motor skills tests. Though he hasn't shown much improvement on these assessments since starting cyclodextrin, he has shown no signs of deterioration.

42.title: Dr. John Pugh: Intrathecal (IT) Cyclodextrin
42.plot: Intrathecal treatment has advantages compared to intravenous treatment because it gets the cyclodextrin closer to its target, which increases the drug's effectiveness and lessens the chance of side effects.

43.title: Dr. John Pugh: Pursuing Cyclodextrin
43.plot: Dr. Shur tapped Dr. Pugh, a neurologist, for a team of doctors focused on pursuing a cyclodextrin treatment for JP.

44.title: Dr. John Pugh: Recommending Cyclodextrin
44.plot: Cyclodextrin, though still in a trial phase, is worth having a conversation about with your doctor.

45.title: Dr. Natasha Shur: Intro
45.plot: Dr. Shur is the division head of Albany Medical Center genetics in the Department of Pediatrics.

46.title: Dr. Natasha Shur: Symptoms of NPC
46.plot: JP's symptoms manifested early on, years before his diagnosis.

47.title: Dr. Natasha Shur: Early Intervention Cyclodextrin
47.plot: In animal studies, test subjects demonstrated less neurotoxicity from NPC when they received cyclodextrin early.

48.title: Dr. Natasha Shur: Results of Cyclodextrin
48.plot: JP has more energy since beginning treatment. Though cyclodextrin isn't a miracle drug, it is an important step toward finding one.

49.title: Dr. Natasha Shur: Intrathecal (IT) Cyclodextrin
49.plot: During JP's intrathecal treatments, 6cc of spinal fluid is removed, and then the same volume of cyclodextrin is injected. At the end of the day, JP still has the energy to play lacrosse.

50.title: Dr. Natasha Shur: Pursuing Cyclodextrin
50.plot: When JP failed to qualify for an NIH cyclodextrin trial, Dr. Shur formed a team at Albany Medical to develop a treatment for him.

51.title: Dr. Natasha Shur: Recommending Cyclodextrin
51.plot: Whether or not you choose cyclodextrin for your child can be a difficult, complex decision.

52.title: Dr. Natasha Shur: The Unknow of Cyclodextrin
52.plot: Cyclodextrin, though not FDA-approved for NPC treatment, is a sugar molecule found in many everyday household products.

53.title: Reedy Family: Family Life
53.plot: "You're going to be devoting most of your 'free' time to pursuing this."

54.title: Reedy Family: Symptoms of NPC
54.plot: "I couldn't put my finger on why his eyes looked weird...it was supranuclear gaze palsy, where they can't look up without moving their head."

55.title: Reedy Family: Using Cyclodextrin
55.plot: "Once a week, bright and early, we drive up to Boston...they run an IV infusion over six hours."

56.title: Reedy Family: Results of Cyclodextrin
56.plot: "He started developing as soon as we put him on it. Chase was able to walk; he wasn't able to walk before that."

57.title: Reedy Family: Pursuing Cyclodextrin
57.plot: Chase's NPC onset very early, which meant Shannon needed to do something quickly to save her son's life.

58.title: Reedy Family: Recommending Cyclodextrin
58.plot: The best immediate option for your child after diagnosis is to try to get added to the NIH's cyclodextrin trial, or to get a physician to write you a protocol for cyclodextrin.

59.title: Reedy Family: Losing Cyclodextrin
59.plot: "The FDA shut us down...he was on a couple other drugs, but he'd been on them for five months. One dose of cyclo had him out of the ICU and on the regular floor."

60.title: Koujaian Family: Symptoms of NPC
60.plot: "...They figured out where the seizures were coming from, and then they operated on her. The seizures continued."

61.title: Koujaian Family: Using Cyclodextrin
61.plot: "The best that we'd hoped for when we started with this journey was stabilizing. She's better than that."

62.title: Koujaian Family: Early Intervention Cyclodextrin
62.plot: "The brain cells that aren't dead, they could be repaired. But anything that is already dead, there's no going back...it's very important to start right away."

63.title: Koujaian Family: Results of Cyclodextrin
63.plot: Since starting cyclodextrin treatment, Hayley has regained the ability to feed herself and use the bathroom, among other improvements.

64.title: Koujaian Family: Hope
64.plot: "Two or three years ago, there was nothing. Now there is."

65.title: Dr. Elizabeth Kravis: Intro
65.plot: Dr. Kravis is a professor of pediatrics, neurological sciences, and biochemistry at Rush University Medical Center in Chicago, IL.

66.title: Dr. Elizabeth Kravis: Results of Cyclodextrin
66.plot: Hayley's ability to walk, turn, and balance has improved as she's been taking cyclodextrin.

67.title: Dr. Elizabeth Kravis: Intrathecal (IT) Cyclodextrin
67.plot: "Outside of the annoyance of having to...spend a day in clinic every two weeks, what we do is really a pretty overall benign process."

68.title: Dr. Elizabeth Kravis: Pursuing Cyclodextrin
68.plot: Hayley didn't qualify for the NIH cyclodextrin trial, so her parents approached Dr. Kravis about doing an IND [Investigational New Drug application].

69.title: Dr. Elizabeth Kravis: Recommending Cyclodextrin
69.plot: Dr. Kravis firmly believes that people with NPC ought to have access to cyclodextrin.

70.title: Marinho Family: Symptoms of NPC
70.plot: "His first symptoms were school-related. He began displaying trouble concentrating. He couldn't focus properly anymore. His writing skills got a lot worse. We had to go through a lot to finally understand what was happening."

71.title: Marinho Family: Using Cyclodextrin
71.plot: "The treatment is a little bit painful because we're still going through the intravenous stage. Things will improve as soon as we move to the intrathecal stage."

72.title: Marinho Family: Results of Cyclodextrin
72.plot: "His ability to swallow improved greatly, he gained more control over his salivation, his involuntary movements also had noticeable improvements...I have nothing but good things to say about cyclodextrin."

73.title: Marinho Family: Pursuing Cyclodextrin
73.plot: "Your doctor needs to be a real companion, committed to the cause, willing to take risks. We, as parents, as family, also have to take the risk. It's our son's life at stake. Without the risks, there would have been no improvement."

74.title: Marinho Family: Recommending Cyclodextrin
74.plot: "Get your children treated with cyclodextrin...it will fight every symptom this disease has plagued our children with."

75.title: Pessoa Family: Symptoms of NPC
75.plot: Marcela began showing symptoms of a degenerative disease when she was seven years old. Six years later, Natália started to show some symptoms of her own, and the Pessoas began to suspect their girls had the same disease.

76.title: Pessoa Family: Using Cyclodextrin
76.plot: After a long search, the Pessoas finally found a local facility willing to administer cyclodextrin to their girls. Six months later, they moved to a home-care system and now administer IV infusions themselves.

77.title: Pessoa Family: Results of Cyclodextrin
77.plot: Two months after starting cyclodextrin treatment, Marcela's writing improved and her seizures stopped, while Natália's psychiatric disabilities disappeared completely.

78.title: Pessoa Family: Pursuing Cyclodextrin
78.plot: With the help of Hugh and Chris Hempel and neuropediatrician Camilo Vieira, the Pessoas finally got approval from the government to begin cyclodextrin treatment.

79.title: Pessoa Family: Recommending Cyclodextrin
79.plot: "This treatment is worth fighting for...five years ago, we couldn't even imagine we'd have such normal lives with our daughters today."

80.title: Dr. Camilo Vieira: Intro
80.plot: Dr. Vieira is a neurologist at Clínica CITTA in Salvador, Bahia, Brazil, an innovative program for the care of children and adolescents with neurological diseases.

81.title: Dr. Camilo Vieira: Symptoms of NPC
81.plot: The girls exhibit different symptoms of NPC - Marcela's affect her motor functions, and Natália's affect her cognitive ability.

82.title: Dr. Camilo Vieira: Using Cyclodextrin
82.plot: After beginning home care, Dr. Vieira worked closely with doctors in the States to ensure that he administered Marcela and Natália's treatment properly.

83.title: Dr. Camilo Vieira: Early Intervention Cyclodextrin
83.plot: "I'd tell them not to waste any time...I've counseled many families to pursue it."

84.title: Dr. Camilo Vieira: Results of Cyclodextrin
84.plot: Cyclodextrin treatment allowed the girls to rejoin society - both could return to school and go out to restaurants and movies.

85.title: Dr. Camilo Vieira: Pursuing Cyclodextrin
85.plot: Dr. Vieira, working closely with the Hempels, managed to import cyclodextrin into Brazil and prescribe it for the girls legally.

86.title: Garrido Family: Symptoms of NPC
86.plot: "Until he was eight years old, he was a normal child. Then, we noticed something was wrong: he could no longer add numbers...it was like we were going backwards."

87.title: Garrido Family: Using Cyclodextrin
87.plot: "In February we were told that we could continue [intrathecal injection], or he could have a little surgery done to put an Ommaya reservoir in his brain."

88.title: Garrido Family: Results of Cyclodextrin
88.plot: Within four days of receiving his first dose of cyclodextrin, Raúl regained a significant amount of coordination.

89.title: Garrido Family: Results of Cyclodextrin Raúl
89.plot: Raúl notices that he's doing better, thanks to cyclodextrin.

90.title: Garrido Family: Pursuing Cyclodextrin
90.plot: "It took us a year and a half to get cyclo...right now, patients diagnosed with Niemann-Pick have only one option: cyclo."

91.title: Lopez Family: Family Life
91.plot: "What can we say? He is the best we have...we love him a lot and he loves us a lot."

92.title: Lopez Family: Symptoms of NPC
92.plot: "We noticed that he had a speech disorder, that he fell down, and that his belly was inflamed...little epileptic fits began to appear."

93.title: Lopez Family: Early Intervention Cyclodextrin
93.plot: "For children that have been diagnosed recently, that don't have this damage yet, that still walk, talk...without a doubt, cyclodextrin will help them a lot."

94.title: Lopez Family: Results of Cyclodextrin
94.plot: When Alberto began using cyclodextrin, Rafael and Edu saw the number of seizures their son had start to decline.

95.title: Lopez Family: Pursuing Cyclodextrin
95.plot: "...after only twenty days, Dr. Muñoz called us and told us, 'Good news - we have cyclodextrin for your son.'"

96.title: Dr. Antonio Munoz: Intro
96.plot: Dr. Muñoz is a professor of pediatrics at the University of Granada. He is director of clinical management of pediatrics at Clinical Hospital San Cecilio and the president of the Pediatric Society of Eastern Andalusia.

97.title: Dr. Antonio Muñoz: Results of Cyclodextrin
97.plot: "The progression he was having has stopped."

98.title: Dr. Antonio Muñoz: Intrathecal (IT) Cyclodextrin
98.plot: "In Alberto's case, it was clear that it was his nervous system that was more damaged...so it seemed logical to administer [cyclodextrin] intrathecally."

99.title: Dr. Antonio Muñoz: Recommending Cyclodextrin
99.plot: "If I had a son, I would administer [cyclodextrin] to him without a doubt."

100.title: Prado Family: Symptoms of NPC
100.plot: "When she was one year old, she started to have her eyelids very swelled and closed. She could hardly open them, especially when she was tired."

101.title: Prado Family: Using Cyclodextrin
101.plot:
Know what this is about?
 Be the first one to add a plot.

102.title: Prado Family: Early Intervention Cyclodextrin
102.plot: "I would like it to be easier for someone who wants to take cyclodextrin...I wish [we'd gotten it] sooner."

103.title: Prado Family: Results of Cyclodextrin
103.plot: "She is much more relaxed. You can leave her alone. She is sitting again. She doesn't have excellent coordination, but she can manipulate things."

104.title: Prado Family: Pursuing Cyclodextrin
104.plot: "You can't stay in your house watching your child fade away. You have to try something."

1.title: Vtesse: Controlled Trial of Cyclodextrin
1.plot: A controlled trial gives Vtesse the best shot at getting VTS-270 approved by regulatory agencies such as FDA and EMA. In a controlled trial, the resulting data from the trial is stronger, and thus more likely to demonstrate VTS-270's efficacy. Furthermore, a controlled study will allow the benefits/risks of VTS-270 to be more precisely understood.

2.title: Vtesse: Future Work
2.plot: Not only would a clinical trial mean getting closer to regulatory approval, it would also allow researchers to take a big first step toward refining VTS-270 and making it even more optimized for treating Niemann-Pick Type C.

3.title: Vtesse: President & CEO
3.plot: Ben is the President and Chief Executive Officer of Vtesse. He has over 25 years of experience in drug development, including participating in the development of the first publicly available vaccine for H1N1 (swine flu). He now brings his expertise to parents and doctors in the fight against NPC. Ben and his wife of over 30 years take great pride in their two children. He enjoys bicycling with his wife and cooking.

4.title: Vtesse: Chief Business Officer
4.plot: Ravi is the Chief Business Officer of Vtesse. Although he was trained as a scientist, his extensive experience in corporate strategy, partnering, collaboration and implementation gives Vtesse the business know-how it needs to make things happen in the fight against NPC. He has been married for 12 years and has two sons.

5.title: Vtesse: Commitment
5.plot: "Our promise is to think about the kids first, to think outside the box where we can, and to deliver on our promises."

6.title: Vtesse: Motivation - Care for Children
6.plot: The chance to help children with no other solutions motivates Ben to get approval for VTS-270.

7.title: Vtesse: Motivation - Personal Involvement
7.plot: While Ben has worked on many drug-development teams, he looks forward to helping the NPC community in a direct and personal way.

8.title: Vtesse: Motivation - Expertise
8.plot: Ravi feels personal responsibility to use the experience he has in drug development to help these kids and families.

9.title: Vtesse: Being a Parent - Ben
9.plot: Ben recalls the nervousness and fear he felt when his daughter went through a simple heart surgery.

10.title: Vtesse: Being a Parent - Ravi
10.plot: As the parent of a 2-year-old and a newborn, Ravi finds great pleasure in seeing the world through the eyes of his son.

1.title: Dr. Cristin Davidson and Dr. Steven Walkley: Intro
1.plot: Dr. Cristin Davidson has been researching treatments for NPC for a decade, including cyclodextrin, a treatment she discovered in early 2006. Dr. Steven Walkley has spent more than 30 years researching lysosomal diseases like NPC.

2.title: Dr. Cristin Davidson and Dr. Steven Walkley: Discovery of Cyclodextrin
2.plot: "The solubilizer was having the effect, not the allopregnanolone...it was a serendipitous discovery."

3.title: Dr. Cristin Davidson and Dr. Steven Walkley: Results of Cyclodextrin
3.plot: "It is by far the most dramatic of any drug that's ever been used in this disease."

4.title: Dr. Cristin Davidson and Dr. Steven Walkley: Researching Cyclodextrin - Collaboration
4.plot: Drs. Davidson and Walkley coordinate with SOAR (Support Of Accelerated Research), a collaboration of multiple labs dedicated to developing NPC treatments.

5.title: Dr. Cristin Davidson and Dr. Steven Walkley: Researching Cyclodextrin - Ototoxicity
5.plot: One of Drs. Davidson and Walkley's main focuses is developing a cyclodextrin treatment that doesn't cause hearing loss.

6.title: Dr. Cristin Davidson and Dr. Steven Walkley: Researching Cyclodextrin - Further Investigation
6.plot: Drs. Davidson and Walkley have been working hard to refine their understanding of cyclodextrin in order to make it even more effective for NPC treatment.

7.title: Dr. Cristin Davidson and Dr. Steven Walkley: FDA Approval - Vtesse Trial
7.plot: "It's really critical to do this trial, to do it properly...so that [cyclodextrin] would be widely available for NPC patients."

8.title: Dr. Kartik Chandran: Intro
8.plot: Dr. Kartik Chandran and his team are at the forefront of Ebola virus research, and discovered the link between the NPC1 gene and Ebola's ability to infect the body.

9.title: Dr. Kartik Chandran: Discovering the NPC-Ebola Link
9.plot: "We essentially took cells and knocked the genes out of them randomly...when you knocked NPC1 out of the cell, Ebola was absolutely unable to infect that cell."

10.title: Dr. Kartik Chandran: Researching the NPC-Ebola Link - Mice
10.plot: When Dr. Chandran and his team gave Ebola to a mouse without the NPC1 gene, they found that the virus was unable to even begin infecting its host.

11.title: Dr. Kartik Chandran: Researching the NPC-Ebola Link - NPC Patient Cells
11.plot: Cells donated by NPC-affected patients through Coriell allow Dr. Chandran's team to continue researching treatments for Ebola and other similar viruses. In turn, Dr. Chandran's detailed research into the NPC1 gene may help develop treatments for NPC.

12.title: Dr. Kartik Chandran: Goals - Therapeutics
12.plot: Dr. Chandran hopes to develop treatments for a range of viral infections by studying the NPC1 gene.

13.title: Dr. Kartik Chandran: Goals - Precise Understanding
13.plot: Dr. Chandran's team focuses on mapping the process by which Ebola affects the NPC1 gene down to the atomic level.

14.title: Dr. Kartik Chandran: Motivation
14.plot: "...by working on really basic aspects of how the virus uses our own cells in our body and exploits them...we could find Achilles' heels for this virus so that we could actually develop a treatment."

1.title: Dr. Forbes Porter: Intro
1.plot: Dr. Porter is the Clinical Director for the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development (NICHD) at the National Institutes of Health (NIH) in Bethesda, MD.

2.title: Dr. Forbes Porter: Getting Involved with NPC
2.plot: Because Dr. Porter has expertise in genetic disorders of cholesterol synthesis, he was asked to join a project researching NPC.

3.title: Dr. Forbes Porter: Natural History Study
3.plot: In order to design a successful clinical trial for potential NPC treatments, Dr. Porter's research group first initiated a natural history study to get baseline data from NPC patients.

4.title: Dr. Forbes Porter: Relating to Parents
4.plot: While it is very emotional, Dr. Porter finds relating to NPC parents and patients extremely rewarding.

5.title: Dr. Forbes Porter: Cyclodextrin Clinical Trial Phase I NIH
5.plot: Dr. Porter is cautiously optimistic that cyclodextrin may be slowing the rate of NPC progression.

6.title: Dr. Forbes Porter: Cyclodextrin Clinical Trial Ototoxicity
6.plot: A number of children in the Phase I trial have had to get hearing aids because of the cyclodextrin treatment they receive, but to date the hearing loss is not severe or untreatable.

7.title: Dr. Forbes Porter: Cyclodextrin Clinical Trial Collaboration at NIH
7.plot: Multiple research groups at the NIH have worked together to advance cyclodextrin as a potential treatment for NPC.

8.title: Dr. Forbes Porter: Cyclodextrin Clinical Trial Phase II (Vtesse)
8.plot: The Phase II trial by Vtesse is critical for proving that cyclodextrin slows NPC progression, so that regulatory agencies will approve cyclodextrin treatment for every person affected by NPC.

9.title: Dr. Forbes Porter: NPC Drug Development - Cyclodextrin
9.plot: Cyclodextrin has a lot of potential as a treatment for NPC, yet it is not going to be a cure. Multiple therapies will be needed to treat different aspects of the disease.

10.title: Dr. Forbes Porter: NPC Drug Development - Other Potential Therapies
10.plot: Due to the advancement of basic science research funded by NPC family groups such as the Ara Parseghian Medical Research Foundation, NNPDF and SOAR, there are multiple potential therapies under investigation, including HDAC and gene therapy.

1.title: Heinze Family: Family Life
1.plot: "We try our best to keep life normal, especially for Serina."

2.title: Heinze Family: Tyler's NPC Story - Symptoms
2.plot: It wasn't until Tyler had trouble walking that Tim and Liz realized something might be wrong. With few treatments available, Tyler's NPC progressed quickly and included symptoms such as ataxia, seizures and difficulty swallowing.

3.title: Heinze Family: Tyler's NPC Story - Diagnostic Odyssey
3.plot: It took about 3 years of seeing doctors and testing before Tyler was officially diagnosed with Niemann-Pick Type C by Dr. Michael Nigro at the Michigan Institute for Neurological Disorders.

4.title: Heinze Family: Katie and Faith - Testing for NPC
4.plot: Liz was pregnant with Faith when she and Tim learned of Tyler's NPC diagnosis. Within a few months of Faith's birth, they tested all of their children for NPC.

5.title: Heinze Family: Katie and Faith - Current Treatment
5.plot: The Heinzes were able to get Zavesca (miglustat) prescribed off-label for their daughters in 2006, but they continue to seek a treatment that will give Katie and Faith the best quality of life.

6.title: Heinze Family: Katie and Faith - Current Condition
6.plot: Katie can barely walk or talk now, and Faith can only walk and talk a little bit, yet they love being with people and are happy to do what they can still do.

7.title: Heinze Family: Serina - Being a Sibling
7.plot: Serina loves being with her sisters and enjoys the close relationships they share.

8.title: Heinze Family: Serina - Helping Out
8.plot: While her parents work on the family dairy farm, Serina helps take care of her sisters and plays games with them.

9.title: Heinze Family: Serina - Giving Medical Care
9.plot: Because Serina has been around NPC since she was a toddler, helping Katie and Faith with medical care - such as using a feeding tube - is normal for her.

10.title: Heinze Family: NPC Parents - A Long Road
10.plot: "There's so many other families that are out there for you...Lean on each other."

11.title: Heinze Family: Vtesse Phase II/III Trial - Pursuing Cyclodextrin
11.plot: The Heinzes seek to get Katie and Faith into the Vtesse trial in order to fight NPC using cyclodextrin.

12.title: Heinze Family: Vtesse Phase II/III Trial - Not FDA Approved
12.plot: Tim and Liz want to help their daughters live longer and healthier lives. They also want to get cyclodextrin approved by the FDA in order to help all people with NPC.

1.title: Dr. Benny Liu: Intro
1.plot:
Know what this is about?
 Be the first one to add a plot.

2.title: Dr. Benny Liu: Discovery of Cyclodextrin - Getting Involved with NPC
2.plot: Dr. Liu began researching NPC shortly after an exciting finding at UCSF that claimed allopregnanolone extended the lives of NPC mice.

3.title: Dr. Benny Liu: Discovery of Cyclodextrin - Research at UTSW
3.plot: Although previous studies said cyclodextrin had no effect on NPC, Dr. Liu included a cyclodextrin-only control when he repeated the UCSF lifespan experiment at UTSW.

4.title: Dr. Benny Liu: Discovery of Cyclodextrin - The Discovery
4.plot: When Dr. Liu saw the results of the experiment, he realized it was actually cyclodextrin - not allopregnanolone - that was responsible for the lifespan extension of NPC mice.

5.title: Dr. Benny Liu: Mechanism of Cyclodextrin
5.plot: "Cyclodextrin...actually released all that trapped cholesterol within the lysosome."

6.title: Dr. Benny Liu: Results of Cyclodextrin - Positive Effects
6.plot: The results of cyclodextrin in mice were very good - more than double the lifespan as well as multiple improvements to their quality of life.

7.title: Dr. Benny Liu: Results of Cyclodextrin - Adverse Effects
7.plot: NPC mice treated with cyclodextrin displayed very few adverse effects.

8.title: Dr. Benny Liu: Results of Cyclodextrin - A Question
8.plot: There's one organ that didn't improve when NPC mice were treated with cyclodextrin, Dr. Liu observed.

9.title: Dr. Benny Liu: The Hempels' Story
9.plot: "As we were developing cyclodextrin as a treatment...Chris Hempel on the other side was starting to really push this for kids with the disease."

10.title: Dr. Benny Liu: Cyclodextrin in NPC Patients - Bench to Bedside
10.plot: Cyclodextrin's transition from the lab to the lives of NPC patients was swift.

11.title: Dr. Benny Liu: Cyclodextrin in NPC Patients - Results
11.plot: Many families have seen NPC disease stabilization in their kids after cyclodextrin treatment.

12.title: Dr. Benny Liu: Roles After the Lab
12.plot: "I'm still involved with cyclodextrin, building it as a treatment...I'm also heavily involved with medical education."

13.title: Dr. Benny Liu: Motivation
13.plot: "We want...to carry this to fruition and provide this drug to all the kids and all the people with NPC."

1.title: Leoni Family: Family Life
1.plot: "She's a fighter. She's determined to keep fighting."

2.title: Leoni Family: Symptoms
2.plot: As a baby, Jessica had jaundice, an enlarged liver and cirrhosis. As she grew up, she began to fall behind developmentally.

3.title: Leoni Family: NPC Diagnosis
3.plot: The diagnosis was devastating for Anthony and Lisa, but it did not change their love for Jessica.

4.title: Leoni Family: Seizures
4.plot: At the age of seven, Jessica started having over one hundred seizures a day, and within the year she lost the ability to walk, talk and eat independently.

5.title: Leoni Family: Changing Doctors' Perspectives
5.plot: "We bring in pictures - especially if we're going to be in the hospital for a while."

6.title: Leoni Family: Motivation to Use Cyclodextrin
6.plot: "There's a possibility that Jessie can be helped and...other children with NPC can be helped as well."

7.title: Leoni Family: Using Cyclodextrin
7.plot: "The cyclodextrin treatment takes about six hours of IV and six to eight hours of observation."

8.title: Leoni Family: Results of Cyclodextrin
8.plot: "One of the markers that they track in the blood had dropped by 75%."

9.title: Leoni Family: Pursuing Cyclodextrin
9.plot: "We'd had quite a bit of communication with other members of the NPC community."

10.title: Leoni Family: Recommending Cyclodextrin
10.plot: Anthony and Lisa recommend cyclodextrin to other families fighting NPC.

11.title: Leoni Family: Hope
11.plot: The Leonis feel hopeful, now, because their daughter Jessica is using cyclodextrin.

12.title: Leoni Family: Cannabis Oil
12.plot: "Jessie hasn't had a seizure in 3 weeks. She's never done that...in 10 years."

imdb.plot outline: Funded by the Brian and Caris Chan Family Foundation and the Liferay Foundation, Fight NPC is an initiative dedicated to empowering families in their struggle against Niemann-Pick Type C. We know it's easy to despair in the face of such an aggressive, deadly disease, but recent medical breakthroughs have given NPC-affected families across the world hope for a better life for their children. Living with NPC is difficult, but we now believe that living with NPC is possible. Don't give up - join us as we fight NPC.
imdb.title: Fight NPC

other companies.name: Brian and Caris Chan Family Foundation

plot: Funded by the Brian and Caris Chan Family Foundation and the Liferay Foundation, _Fight NPC_ (qv) is an initiative dedicated to empowering families in their struggle against Niemann-Pick Type C. We know it's easy to despair in the face of such an aggressive, deadly disease, but recent medical breakthroughs have given NPC-affected families across the world hope for a better life for their children. Living with NPC is difficult, but we now believe that living with NPC is possible. Don't give up - join us as we fight NPC.
